Specific Details: Declaration for 'Socially Responsible Connectivity' in Europe
DPOs Lobbied: Kieran O'Donnell|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Declaration for 'Socially Responsible Connectivity' in Europe
Intended Results: To inform the Chair of the Joint Committee on Transport of the Declaration signed by 8 EU member states and to request that the Irish Government sign the Declaration. The Joint declaration calls for socially responsible air connectivity in Europe, where social rights are safeguarded, safety is further enhanced and competition is based on fair conditions rather than on dumping practices.' IALPA also requested a meeting to discuss this issue further.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Capt. Evan Cullen - President of Irish Air Line Pilots Association (IALPA)

Intended Results: Adjustment to the new service change for route 303 and 303A, Limerick to reinstate the former route course for 303 and 303A for the benefit of the community who have been discommoded by the changes.

Specific Details: Update on the Implementation of the medical Device Regulation and its impact of Patients, end users and Cook. In particular we wanted to highlight the following. Unless immediate action is taken, Europe faces a scenario where a high number of existing medical  devices, upon which patients, hospitals and other health institutions rely, will fail to be re-certified on  time and therefore risk to permanently disappear from the market.
DPOs Lobbied: Deirdre Clune|MEP|European Parliament::Seán Kelly|MEP|European Parliament::Billy Kelleher|MEP|European Parliament::Kieran O'Donnell|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Update on the Implementation of the medical Device Regulation and its impact of Patients, end users and Cook. In particular we wanted to highlight the following. Unless immediate action is taken, Europe faces a scenario where a high number of existing medical  devices, upon which patients, hospitals and other health institutions rely, will fail to be re-certified on  time and therefore risk to permanently disappear from the market.
Intended Results: A legislative change to the the existing MDR to target three areas requiring change.  (1)	Extend the validity of the Medical Devices Directive and Active Implantable Medical Devices Directive Certificates: (2) Allow conditional/temporary MDR certification: to maintain access to existing devices, (3) Abolish the MDR Article 120(4) ‘warehousing’ deadline:
Lobbying Activities: Emails sent to some of the Irish MEPs during the the final Qtr. of 2022.|Email|6-10::Face to Face meeting with Deirdre Clune MEP in Brussels as part of a delegation from IBEC and the Irish Medtech Association|Meeting|1

Specific Details: Commercial Rates on Farm Buildings
DPOs Lobbied: Kieran O'Donnell|Minister of State|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Commercial Rates on Farm Buildings
Intended Results: To highlight the increasing number of cases, some of which are more concentrated in certain regions, where valuation office inspectors are deeming primary production sites rateable. These are predominantly impacting horticulture and tillage farmers, many of whom are currently running their business at or below the cost of production.::To highllight that, under the Valuation Act 2001 in Schedule 4, it refers to 'Relevant Property Not Rateable' which includes the following::- 1. Agricultural land, 2. Land developed for horticulture, 3. Land developed for forestry, 4. Land developed for sport, 5. Farm Buildings.....::The Valuation Act part 1, section 3, paragraph 7 also gives a definition of farm buildings as (c) buildings, parts of buildings, or other structures, occupied together with land developed for horticulture or forestry and used solely in connection with the carrying on of horticultural or forestry activities.::To seek a meeting with Minister of State Kieran O'Donnell to discuss these issues.

Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Tim Cullinan IFA President,  Elaine Farrell IFA Director of Governance & Oireachtas Engagement, Sean Ryan IFA Potato Chair, Tadhg Buckley IFA Director of Policy & Chief Economist, Niamh Brennan IFA Policy Executive, Karol Kissane IFA Senior Policy Executive,

Specific Details: Refunds under Section 58 Value-Added Tax (VAT)
DPOs Lobbied: Grant Sweetnam|Special Adviser|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Kevin Barrett|Special Adviser|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Kieran O'Donnell|Minister of State|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Refunds under Section 58 Value-Added Tax (VAT)
Intended Results: To highlight that many items of a fixed nature have always received refunds of VAT. However, in the past number of months, it has been brought to IFA's attention that items the VAT could previously be reclaimed upon, such as automatic calf feeders, robotic scraping systems, drafting gates and bulk milk tanks, have now been refused refunds by Revenue. This change in the interpretation of the relevant legislation has been abrupt and without any communication or engagement.::To challenge this change in interpretation of the S.I. by Revenue, which is causing major issues at farm level. For many farmers such large capital expenditure is financed by bank lending, and the amount financed would be the VAT exclusive amount because of the expectation that the VAT incurred would be refunded.::To highlight that these farmers now face the situation where the amount borrowed no longer covers the expenditure incurred and may struggle to find further finance to fill this shortfall. In addition, many who had planned expenditure on such items are now reconsidering such expenditure due to this extra cost.::That the issue this change of interpretation is also causing, is with the Targeted Agriculture Modernisation Schemes (TAMS) grant funding. The ceilings for items under TAMS are set as the VAT exclusive amount in most instances, again with the expectation that the VAT incurred would be refunded. If as it appears this is no longer the case for such items, then the ceiling for those items needs to be adjusted up accordingly and further funding allocated to the TAMS.::To request a meeting with the Minister for Finance to engage further on this issue.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Tim Cullinan IFA President, Rose Mary McDonagh IFA Farm Business Chair, Nigel Sweetnam IFA Poultry Chair, Karol Kissane IFA Senior Policy Executive, Sarah Hanley IFA Policy Executive

Specific Details: Flooding of the Shannon Callows
DPOs Lobbied: Kieran O'Donnell|Minister of State|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage
Subject Matter: Flooding of the Shannon Callows
Intended Results: To seek a meeting with the Minister to discuss the best way to manage the River Shannon.::To discuss how the River Shannon is managed from top to bottom (cleaning and maintenance of the Shannon, the fact that the river is overgrown which stops the flow of water, leading to flooding).::To discuss how necessary remedial works can be carried out when they are necessary and not after disaster has occurred.::To discuss current legislation and directives and how this can be balanced – timeframe for River Shannon Management Agency Bill::To seek answers on how to protect the Shannon, the wildlife, the environment and working within that to protect people's livelihoods and homes.::To discuss the controlling of lough gates for managing water levels.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brendan Golden IFA Flood Project Team Chair, Claire McGlynn IFA Policy Executive
